terms.definition: Dishonestly inducing someone to deliver any property, or to consent to retain any property, or to do or omit to do anything which they would not do or omit if they were not so deceived, thereby causing harm or damage.
Illegally entering or remaining on someone else's property with the intent to commit an offense, intimidate, insult, or annoy.
Deceiving someone with malicious intent to cause them to hand over or give up possession of their property.
The act of creating a false valuable security or altering a genuine one with the intent to deceive or cause harm, making it appear as if it were a legitimate document.
Papers or records that have been created, altered, or used dishonestly to deceive, cheat, or obtain an unfair advantage.
An abbreviation for the Indian Penal Code.
The principal criminal code of India, which defines various criminal offenses and specifies their punishments.
A situation where a claim of ownership over a property is not legally recognized or supported by proper title or rights.
A assertion of ownership or right over a property that is not legally justifiable or supported by valid title.
The person or entity recognized by law as having legitimate title, rights, and control over a property.
A formal written communication from one party to another, informing them of a legal matter, demand, or impending legal action.
A distinct part or subdivision of a legal act, code, or document, usually dealing with a specific topic.
A government office responsible for officially recording and registering documents, particularly those related to property transactions, in a specific jurisdiction.
An Indian law that regulates the transfer of property, specifically between living persons, covering aspects like sale, mortgage, lease, exchange, and gift.
The act of holding or occupying property without legal permission, right, or title from the rightful owner.
A document that legally creates, extends, transfers, restricts, extinguishes, or releases any legal right, or which acknowledges that a person has a legal liability or right.
Officials, government bodies, or organizations that possess the legal power and jurisdiction to address or decide a particular matter.
To dishonestly create false documents or alter genuine ones, usually with the intention to deceive or defraud.
Statements or actions that are untrue and presented as if they were facts, often with intent to deceive.
Methods or actions used to deceive or cheat someone for personal gain or to cause harm.
The state of being confined in a prison or correctional facility as a punishment for a crime.
The punishments or legal penalties that are imposed as a result of committing a crime or violating a law.
An act or omission that is prohibited by law and for which a penalty, such as a fine or imprisonment, can be imposed.
A legal document that officially transfers ownership or rights of property from one party to another and has been recorded with the relevant government authority.
The individual or entity who legally possesses and has legitimate title to a particular property or asset.
A legal document that proves the sale and transfer of ownership of a property from the seller to the buyer.
Refers to a specific property that has been previously mentioned or identified in a legal document or discussion.
A legal paper used to officially record and effect the movement of ownership or rights of an asset from one party to another.
The act of moving ownership, possession, or rights of something without legal authority or proper procedure.
In a manner that is contrary to or forbidden by law.
A legal transaction that successfully moves ownership or rights from one party to another in accordance with all applicable laws and procedures.
